Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AVATOL - Next Generation Phenomics for the Tree of Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
Darwin's theory of evolution explained that millions of species are related, and dealt biologists and paleontologists the enormous challenge of discovering the branching pattern of the Tree of Life. Work on this great challenge is producing a map of species-relatedness through Earth history, and answering questions such as "what is the closest relative of a species?" and "what species make important products?" To do this scientists draw on all heritable features, including genotypes (e.g., DNA) and phenotypes (e.g., anatomy). Studying phenotypes, however, has remained complicated and slow, because it has not been revolutionized by computer science and engineering innovations.

A team of biologists, computer scientists, and paleontologists will extend and adapt methods from computer vision, machine learning, crowd-sourcing and natural language processing to enable rapid and automated study of phenotypes for the Tree of Life on a vast scale. The three-year goal is to release large phenomic datasets built using new methods, and to provide the public and scientific community with tools for future work. Planned is the training of teachers and students (kindergarten - postdoctoral levels) and the engagement of "citizen scien-tists." Enormous phenomic datasets, many with images, will fill an important public interest in biodiversity and the fossil record.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Although not visible to the naked eye, microscopic organisms are all around us, in us, and in every environment that is examined. Most people know about disease causing microorganisms, yet those are a very small percentage of the overall biodiversity of microorganisms. In the last couple decades new microorganisms have been discovered primarily by detecting their unique deoxynucleic acid (DNA) sequences. These sequences are compared for how closely they match each other, and the similarity is represented on what scientists call a phylogenetic tree of microbial life, analogous to a family tree used to represent relationships of our ancestors. Beyond DNA similarity of microorganisms, what other characteristics traits might they have? Characteristic traits are referred to as phenotypes and can be such things as cell shape of the microorganism, what temperature range they can tolerate, whether they are resistant to any antibiotics, and what function do they serve in the environment. Taken together, the overall phenotypic traits for an organism is known as its phenome.

Phenomic information isn’t easy to collect and generally requires having the microorganism isolated in a pure culture. But with many microorganisms uncultured and known only by their DNA sequences, understanding what makes each microorganism unique is challenging. Many powerful ways are being developed to characterize uncultured microorganisms known only from their DNA sequences in the environment; however, many of these approaches require prior knowledge of phenotypes from previously cultured microorganisms. Fortunately, a lot of phenotypic information has been published about microorganisms in scientific journals, particularly when new microorganisms are described, given a name and classified, a field of biology referred to as taxonomy. This wealth of published taxonomic information can be used to better understand the microbial diversity represented by the phylogenetic tree of life.

Collecting microbial phenomic information published in scientific journals is a slow, tedious process if done manually. Thus, a new approach was needed to speed up the process. Part of the NSF funded project, Next Generation Phenomics for the Tree of Life, was to help develop this approach. In collaboration with other microbiologists and computer information scientists, we developed a computer program to automatically extract microbial phenomic information. The program, Microbial Phenomic Information Extractor (MicroPIE), uses machine learning technology to process taxonomic descriptions of microorganisms found in scientific journal articles. It then put this information into a table format (or matrix) with microbial names for the rows and their phenotypic traits in columns. MicroPIE is open-source, accessible at https://github.com/biosemantics/micropie2, and described in Mao et al (2016) BMC Bioinformatics 17:528.

Developing MicroPIE wasn’t as straightforward as it might sound. We needed to “teach” the computer program how to understand the language used to describe microorganisms by providing thousands of examples of microbial taxonomic descriptions of microbes and developing a list of terms used to describe microorganisms, called a microbial ontology (MicrO), which is deposited at https://github.com/carrineblank/MicrO and is described in Blank et al (2016) Journal of Biomedical Semantics 7:18.

In order to test how well MicroPIE extracted phenotypic traits, we manually compiled a “gold standard matrix” (GSM) with the help of undergraduate students at the University of Southern Maine. By comparing the phenotypic character matrix output by MicroPIE to the GSM we found that MicroPIE performed with >80% accuracy on 21 character traits (such as cell shape and salt range for growth) and moderately well (50–80%) on an additional 16 character traits (such as organic substrates used for growth). Additionally, we incorporated MicroPIE into an online suite of programs called Explorer of Taxon Concepts (ETC, http://etc.cs.umb.edu/etcsite/start.html) so it can be used without downloading the program.

In order to further improve the extraction for some of the character traits, we developed a neural network approach for MicroPIE to recognize terms and their relationships. Again, this required training sentences, but in this case with terms “annotated” in the sentences. With these large training sets, the neural network model approach has improved the extraction of 9 out of 11 characters. The neural network models that were implemented can be found at https://github.com/vikas95/Pref_Suff_Span_NN and will be published soon.

In summary, this NSF funded project enabled a team of microbiologists and computer programmers to work together to develop open-source software (MicroPIE) that can quickly (within hours rather than days) and accurately extract phenomic information about microorganisms from published taxonomic descriptions. We also pulled together the most thorough ontology of microbial terms (MicrO) that will be integrated with MicroPIE on the ETC website. Finally, we published a book chapter outlining a process that others can follow to study microbial evolution: Blank et al. (2018) in Application of Semantic Technologies in Biodiversity Science. We encourage people to use and improve MicroPIE and MicrO.
